The program covers introductory methods to advanced concepts in the second year and provides opportunities for students to network with industry, participate in competitions, work on applied research projects, volunteer, and attend industry events. Extensive sewing experience and access to a sewing machine outside of campus facilities are required.

Graduates of this program may find career opportunities in various roles such as pattern drafting or construction, drafting and construction specifications, product development, assistant designers, technical designers, patternmakers, samplemakers, assistant apparel technicians, graders, marker makers, technical illustrators, product developers, stylists, design, trend and style consultants, and social media. Graduates with a minimum program GPA of 2.7 are eligible for admission to George Brown postgraduate programs.

The learning environment at the School of Fashion and Jewellery is diverse, and there are many extracurricular activities to take advantage of. The fashion show and portfolio event highlight successful student projects. The program requires students to study through the spring/summer semester and continue into the September academic year for a duration of 1.5 years for those starting in January. Both manual dexterity and good vision are assets for this program. Career opportunities range from small design studios to large manufacturing companies, and some graduates have also become entrepreneurs in design, sewing, and fashion service bureaus.
